tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
In this psalm David asks God for forgiveness.
"This is for the director of music to use in worship."
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: when Nathan the prophet came to him
tn.text: It can be stated clearly what Nathan did when he came to David, because this psalm is in response to that. AT: "when Nathan the prophet came to David and rebuked him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: after he had slept with Bathsheba
tn.text: "after David had slept with Bathsheba"

tn.ref: for the sake of the multitude of your merciful actions
tn.text: "because you do so many merciful things"

Forgiving sins is spoken of as either 1) blotting them out or 2) erasing a written record of the sins. AT: "forgive my sins like someone wiping something away" or "forget my sins like someone who erases a record of sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Wash me thoroughly from my iniquity ... cleanse me from my sin
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Wash me thoroughly from my iniquity
tn.text: Being acceptable to God is spoken of as being clean. God makes people acceptable by forgiving their sins.  AT:  "Wash away all my sin" or "Forgive all my sins so that I will be acceptable to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"completely"

Being acceptable to God is spoken of as being clean. God makes people acceptable by forgiving their sins.  AT: "Make me clean from my sin" or "forgive me for my sin so that I will be clean" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: my sin is always before me
tn.text: Not being able to forget his sins is spoken of as if they were always in front of him where he can see them. AT: "I am always aware of my sins" or "I cannot forget my sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"and I have done what is evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: See, I was born in iniquity ... See, you desire trustworthiness
tn.text: The two uses of "See" here draw our attention to the contrast between these two situations. AT: "Truly I was born in iniquity ... But you desire trustworthiness"

tn.ref: See, I was born in iniquity ... as soon as my mother conceived me, I was in sin
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are used together for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Being a sinner is spoken of as being in iniquity. AT: "I was already a sinner when I was born" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: as soon as my mother conceived me, I was in sin
tn.text: Being a sinner is spoken of as being in sin. AT: "even when my mother conceived me, I was a sinner" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you desire trustworthiness in my heart
tn.text: The heart represents either 1) the person's desires or 2) the whole person. AT: "You want me to desire trustworthiness" or "you want me to be trustworthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Purify me ... I will be clean ... wash me ... I will be whiter than snow
tn.text: Being acceptable to God is spoken of as being clean or white. God makes people acceptable by forgiving their sins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The writer speaks of God as if God were a priest who would sprinkle water on him to make him  acceptable to God. AT: "Make me acceptable by sprinkling water on me with hyssop" or "Forgive me for my sins so that I will be acceptable to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a plant that the priests used to sprinkle water or blood on people or things to make them ceremonially clean, that is, acceptable to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
Not having sin is spoken of as being white. AT: "very, very white" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize his desire to hear joyful things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: so that the bones that you have broken may rejoice
tn.text: Feeling terrible sadness is spoken of as if his bones were broken. AT: "for you have caused me terrible sadness in my inner being. Let me rejoice again!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Hide your face from my sins
tn.text: Thinking about someone's sins is spoken of as seeing them. Forgiving or refusing to think about the sins is spoken of as choosing not to see them. AT: "Do not look at my sins" or "Do not remember my sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Forgiving or refusing to think about someone's sins is spoken of as either 1) blotting them out or 2) erasing a written record of the sins. AT: 1) "forgive my sins like someone wiping something away" or "forget my sins like someone who erases a record of sins" (See: Metaphor)

tn.ref: Create in me a clean heart
tn.text: Here the "heart" represents the feelings and desires. Being completely devoted and obedient to God is spoken of as having a clean heart. AT: "Make me completely devoted to you" or "Make me want to obey you always" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: renew a right spirit within me
tn.text: Here "spirit" represents the attitude and desires of a David.  AT: "make my attitude right" or "make me always want to do what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Do not drive me away from your presence
tn.text: "Do not force me to go away from you." Being rejected by God is spoken of as being forced to go away from him. AT: "Do not reject me as one of your people" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"and hold me up" or "assist me"
"the way you want people to live" or "what you want people to do"
These two words refer to the same people here.
This phrase refers to killing another person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Lord, open my lips, and my mouth will express your praise
tn.text: Being able to talk is spoken of as the lips being open. Here not being able to speak is a symbol of being guilty of sin and not being able to make a defense. AT: "Lord, make me able to speak, and I will praise you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you do not delight in sacrifice ... you have no pleasure in burnt offerings
tn.text: This means that God wants something more important than these things. AT: "A sacrifice is not enough to please you ... you want something more than burn offerings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"The sacrifices that please God"
A broken spirit represents a humble attitude. AT: "humility" or "a person who becomes humble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: a broken and a contrite heart
tn.text: Being humble and sorry for one's sin is spoken of as having a broken and contrite heart. The heart represents the emotions and will. AT: "sorrow and humility" or "a person who is sorry for his sin and humble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

The walls of a city protect the city and the people in it. Possible meanings are 1) "enable us to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem" or 2) "protect Jerusalem and make it strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: our people will offer bulls on your altar
tn.text: A bull is an adult male cow. Bulls were often used as sacrificial animals, according to God's instruction.
